P. Dutton books]] [[Category:1959 children's books]]

{{Use Indian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox islands | name = Nicobar Islands | native_name = | sobriquet = | image_name = Nicobar Islands.PNG | image_size = | image_caption = Location of the Nicobar Islands in the Indian Ocean. | image_alt = | map_image = Nicobar Islands.jpg | location = [[Bay of Bengal]] | map = India Andaman and Nicobar Islands#India | map_caption = Location of Nicobar Islands in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands | coordinates = {{Coord|7|05|N|93|48|E|region:IN_type:isle|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] | total_islands = 22 | major_islands = [[Car Nicobar]], [[Great Nicobar]], [[Little Nicobar]] | area_km2 = 1,841 | area_footnotes = | rank = | length_km = | length_footnotes = | width_km = | width_footnotes = | coastline_km = | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_m = 642 | elevation_footnotes = | highest_mount = Mount Thullier | country = India | country_admin_divisions_title = Union territory | country_admin_divisions = [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = | country_admin_divisions_1 = | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = | country_admin_divisions_2 = | country_capital = [[Port Blair]] | country_largest_city = [[Malacca, Car Nicobar]] | country_largest_city_population = 1,637 | country_leader_name = | demonym = | population = [http://censusindia.gov.in/2011-prov-results/prov_data_products_ani.html 36,842] | population_as_of = 2011 | density_km2 = 20 | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = [[Nicobarese]]
[[Shompen]]
[[Indian people|Mainland Indians]] | timezone1 = [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] | utc_offset1 = +5:30 | timezone1_DST = {{nowrap|not observed}} | utc_offset1_DST = +5:30 | website = [http://www.and.nic.in www.and.nic.in] | additional_info = }} The '''Nicobar Islands''' are an [[archipelago|archipelagic]] island chain in the eastern [[Indian Ocean]]. They are located in [[Southeast Asia]], 150 km north of [[Aceh]] on [[Sumatra]], and separated from [[Thailand]] to the east by the [[Andaman Sea]]. Located 1,300 km southeast of the [[Indian subcontinent]], across the [[Bay of Bengal]], they form part of the [[Union Territory]] of [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]], [[India]]. [[UNESCO]] has declared the [[Great Nicobar Island]] as one of the [[World Network of Biosphere Reserves]].[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/multimedia/photos/mab-2013/], The International Coordinating Council of UNESCO’s Man and the Biosphere Programme (MAB), added the following new sites to the World Network of Biosphere Reserves (WNBR) http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/multimedia/photos/mab-2013/india/. ==Geography and population== The Nicobar Islands cover a land area of 1,841 km2[https://www.britannica.com/place/Nicobar-Islands Nicobar Islands]. Encyclopedia Britannica. and had a population of 36,844 during the [[2011 Census of India|2011 Census]]. They comprise three distinct groups: '''[[Car Nicobar Subdivision|Northern Group]]''': * [[Car Nicobar]] * Battimaly '''[[Nancowry Subdivision|Central Group]]''': * [[Chowra]], Chaura or Sanenyo * [[Teressa (Nicobar Islands)|Teressa]] or Luroo * [[Bompuka]] or Poahat * [[Katchal Island|Katchal]] * [[Camorta Island|Camorta]] * [[Nancowry Island|Nancowry]] or Nancowrie * [[Trinket Island|Trinket]] * [[Man Island (Nicobar)|Laouk]] or "Isle of Man" * [[Tillangchong]] '''[[Great Nicobar Subdivision|Southern Group]]''' (Sambelong): * [[Great Nicobar]] (922 km², largest island of the Nicobars) * [[Little Nicobar]] * [[Kondul Island]] * [[Pulo Milo]] or Pillomilo (Milo Island) * [[Meroe Island|Meroe]], Trak, Treis, Menchal, Kabra, Pigeon and Megapod Indira Point ({{coord|6.756378|93.827765}}) is the southernmost point of Great Nicobar Island and also of India itself, lying about 150 km north of [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]]. ==Nature== [[File:Caloenas nicobarica1.jpg|thumb|A [[Nicobar pigeon]]. While named after the Nicobar Islands, it is also found widely in the [[Malay Archipelago]]]] {{See also|Endemic birds of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands}} The Nicobar Islands are part of a great [[island arc]] created by the collision of the [[Indo-Australian Plate]] with [[Eurasia]]. The collision lifted the [[Himalayas]] and most of the Indonesian islands, and created a long arc of highlands and islands, which includes the [[Arakan Yoma]] range of [[Burma]], the Andaman and Nicobar islands, and the islands off the west coast of [[Sumatra]], including the [[Banyak Islands]] and [[Mentawai Islands]]. ===Ecology=== The climate is warm and tropical, with temperatures ranging from 22 to 30 °C. Rainfall is heavy due to annual monsoons and measures around 3000 to 3800 mm each year. The vegetation of the Nicobars is typically divided into the coastal [[mangrove]] forests and the interior evergreen and deciduous [[Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]]. Additionally, several islands contain extensive inland [[grassland]]s, though these are thought to result from human intervention. The Nicobar Islands are recognised as a distinct [[terrestrial ecoregion]], the '''Nicobar Islands rain forests''', with many [[endemic (ecology)|endemic]] species. As a result of lower sea levels during the [[ice age]]s, the Andaman Islands were linked to the Southeast Asian mainland, but it is not believed that the Nicobar Islands ever had a land bridge to the continent. Lower sea levels did link the islands to one another: Great Nicobar and Little Nicobar were linked to each other, and Nancowry, Chaura, Katchall, Trinka, Camorta, and the nearby smaller islands were linked to one another as well. ==History== === Prehistory === The Nicobar Islands are believed to have been inhabited for thousands of years. Six indigenous [[Nicobarese languages]] are spoken on the islands, which are part of the [[Mon–Khmer languages|Mon–Khmer branch]] of the [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic language family]], which includes [[Mon language|Mon]], [[Khmer language|Khmer]] and [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] languages of [[Southeast Asia]], and the [[Munda languages]] of India. An indigenous tribe living at the southern tip of Great Nicobar, called the [[Shompen people|Shompen]], may be of [[Mesolithic]] Southeast Asian origin.{{cite journal | author = Rajni Trivedi| url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/e7n73nq734w71600/ | title = Molecular insights into the origins of the Shompen, a declining population of the Nicobar archipelago | journal = Journal of Human Genetics | issue = 3 | volume = 51 | date = March 2006 | doi = 10.1007/s10038-005-0349-2 | pages = 217–226 | pmid = 16453062 |display-authors=etal}} === Origin of the name === The earliest extant references to the name "Nicobar" is in the [[Sri Lanka]]n [[Pali]] [[Buddhist]] chronicles, the ''[[Dipavamsa]]'' (c. 3rd or 4th century CE) and the ''[[Mahavamsa]]'' (c. 4th or 5th century), which state that the children of the followers of the legendary founder of the Sri Lankan Kingdom, Vijaya, landed on ''Naggadipa'' (the island of the children, from the Pali '''nagga''' meaning 'naked').{{Cite book | title=The Mahavamsa or The Great Chronicle of Ceylon| author=Wilhelm Geiger (Tr)| year=1912 | accessdate= 8 July 2013| publisher=Pali Text Society | url=http://what-buddha-said.net/library/pdfs/mahavamsa.geiger.pdf| quote= ''P54 "The island where the children landed was called Naggadipa..." N: "l That is,'Island of children', from nagga 'naked'..." ''| isbn= 978-81-206-0218-2}} The modern name is likely derived from the [[Chola dynasty]] name for the islands, '''''Nakkavaram''''' or ''''Puup Pii'''' (literally, "naked man" in [[Tamil language|Tamil]]) which is inscribed on the [[Thanjavur]] (Tanjore) inscription of 1050 CE.{{Cite book | title=Ancient Jaffna| author=C Rasanayagam| year=1926 | accessdate= | publisher=Asian Educational Society (reprint)| url=| quote= ''P53 "Naggadipa, where the children are alleged to have landed, is certainly Nicobars, the Nakkavaram of the Tamils, ...''| isbn= 978-81-206-0210-6}}{{Cite book | title=India: A History | author=John Keay | year=2001 | accessdate= | publisher=Grove Press | url=https://books.google.com/?id=ibLUu6RlvqwC | quote=''... and 'Nakkavaram' certainly represents the Nicobar islands ...'' | isbn=978-0-8021-3797-5}}{{Cite book | title=The New Encyclopædia Britannica | year=1998 | accessdate = 16 November 2008 | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica | url=https://books.google.com/?id=abRYAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... The name Nicobar probably is derived from Nakkavaram ("Land of the Naked") ...'' | isbn=978-0-85229-633-2}} [[Marco Polo]] (12th-13th century) also referred to this island as 'Necuverann'. === Colonial period === The history of organised European [[colonisation]] on the islands began with the [[Danish East India Company]] in 1754/56. During this time they were administrated from [[Tranquebar]] (in continental [[Danish India]]) administrated under the name of '''Frederiksøerne'''; missionaries from the [[Moravian Church]] Brethren's settlement in [[Tranquebar]] attempted a settlement on [[Nancowry Island|Nancowry]] and died in great numbers from disease; the islands were repeatedly abandoned due to outbreaks of [[malaria]]: 1784–1807/09, 1830–1834 and finally from 1848 gradually for good. Between 1778 and 1783, [[William Bolts]] attempted to establish an Austrian colony on the islands on the mistaken assumption that [[Denmark–Norway]] had abandoned its claims to the islands.{{cite web |url = http://www.colonialvoyage.com/DanishP.html |title = Chronoly of Danish Colonial Settlements |first = Marco |last = Ramerini |publisher = ColonialVoyage.com |accessdate = January 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050404001731/http://www.colonialvoyage.com/DanishP.html |archivedate = 4 April 2005 |df = dmy-all }} [[Italy]] made an attempt at buying the Nicobar Islands from Denmark between 1864 and 1868. The Italian Minister of Agriculture and Commerce [[Luigi Torelli]] started a negotiation that looked promising, but failed due to the unexpected end of his Office and the [[:it:Governo La Marmora I|first La Marmora Cabinet]]. The negotiations were interrupted and never brought up again.Ministero della Guerra, Ufficio Storico, Storia Militare della Colonia Eritrea, Vol. I, Roma 1935, pp. 15-16 [[Denmark]]'s presence in the islands ended formally on 16 October 1868 when it sold the rights to the Nicobar Islands to Britain, which in 1869 made them part of [[British India]]. ===World War II=== During [[World War II]], the islands were [[Invasion and occupation of the Andaman Islands during World War II|occupied by Japan between 1942 and 1945]]. India occupied these islands after the [[Surrender of Japan]], as its Territory. ===Indian state=== Together with the Andaman Islands, they became a [[union territory]] of India in 1950. == Water sports == Andaman and Nicobar islands are also known for the various types of water sports available. Water sports include snorkeling, scuba diving, parasailing, under-sea walking and other thrilling sports. Water sports is one main cause of the huge tourist attraction to this place. People can enjoy with their families and prefer to relax or excite themselves. ==26 December 2004 tsunami== On 26 December 2004, the coast of the Nicobar Islands was devastated by a 10–15 m high [[tsunami]] following the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]]. At least 6,000 people were killed on the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] with reports putting the death toll on [[Katchal Island]] alone at 4,600. Several islands were heavily damaged with initial reports of islands broken in two or three pieces and coral reefs moved above water. Teressa Island was said to have been split into two pieces and Trinkat Island into three pieces. Some estimates said that the islands were moved as much as 100 feet (30 m) by the earthquake and tilted. [[Indira Point]] subsided 4.25 m and the lighthouse there was damaged. ==World Biosphere Reserve== On 31 May 2013 it was reported that Nicobar Islands have been declared as [[World Biosphere Reserve]] by [[UNESCO]].{{cite news|title=''Nicobar Islands declared as world biosphere reserve''|publisher=[[The Times of India]]|date=31 May 2013|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/flora-fauna/Nicobar-Islands-declared-as-world-biosphere-reserve/articleshow/20358478.cms|accessdate=31 May 2013}} ==Transportation== *Airport: [[Car Nicobar]] CBD/VECX has an airstrip on [[Car Nicobar Air Force Base]] of 2717 by 43 meters on the South East coast near Malacca but does not offer commercial service. [[Great Nicobar]] has a small airstrip of approximately 1000 meters at Campbell Bay/Tenlaa on its East coast. *Seaport: At least one small shipping dock is located in Campbell Bay on the East coast of [[Great Nicobar]]. [[Car Nicobar]] has a small dock at its Northern tip near Keating Point and Mus. ==See also== {{Portal|India}} *[[Nicobarese people]] *[[Nicobarese languages]] *[[Shompen people]] *[[1881 Nicobar Islands earthquake]] * [[Great Nicobar Biosphere Reserve]] * [[Great Nicobar]] * [[Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370]] * [[Indian Ocean]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{commons category}} * {{cite web |url = http://www.andaman.org/NICOBAR/text.htm |title = Nicobarese and Shompen |publisher = The Andaman Association |accessdate = January 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110709082928/http://www.andaman.org/NICOBAR/text.htm |archivedate = 9 July 2011 |df = dmy-all }} *[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/India_BrProvinces.htm#Andaman%20and%20Nicobar WorldStatesmen- India] *[http://dsc.nrsc.gov.in:14000/DSC/Tsunami/CaseStudies.jsp?state=ANDAMAN_NICOBAR%20ISLANDS Post-tsunami satellite photos from India's National Remote Sensing Centre]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [http://vimaln.blogspot.com/2004/12/satellite-pictures-of-tsunami-2004.html (Alternate Link)] {{clear}} {{Danish overseas empire|nocat=yes}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Andaman and Nicobar Islands| Nicobar]] [[Category:Archipelagoes of the Indian Ocean]] [[Category:Archipelagoes of Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Islands of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] [[Category:Bay of Bengal]] [[Category:British India]] [[Category:Danish India]] [[Category:Ecoregions of India]] [[Category:Indomalaya ecozone]] [[Category:Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]] [[Category:Maritime Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Regions of India]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1950]] [[Category:Pleistocene volcanoes]] [[Category:Volcanoes of India]] [[Category:Archipelagoes of India]] [[Category:1754 establishments in the Danish colonial empire]] [[Category:1868 establishments in the British Empire]]

{{short description|A major circulating system of ocean currents}} [[File: North Pacific Subtropical Convergence Zone.jpg|thumb|Significant ocean currents involved in the circulation of the North Pacific Subtropical and Subpolar gyres]] The '''North Pacific Gyre''' (NPG) or '''North Pacific Subtropical Gyre''' (NPSG), located in the northern [[Pacific Ocean]], is one of the five major [[oceanic gyre]]s. This gyre covers most of the northern [[Pacific Ocean]]. It is the largest ecosystem on Earth, located between the [[equator]] and [[50th parallel north|50° N latitude]], and comprising 20 million square kilometers.<ref>{{cite journal | jstor=3658829| title=A Sea of Change: Biogeochemical Variability in the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre|year=1999 |publisher=Springer|volume=2|pages=181–214|doi=10.1007/s100219900068|journal=Ecosystems | last1 = Karl | first1 = David M.}}</ref> The gyre has a clockwise circular pattern and is formed by four prevailing [[ocean current]]s: the [[North Pacific Current]] to the north, the [[California Current]] to the east, the [[North Equatorial Current]] to the south, and the [[Kuroshio Current]] to the west. It is the site of an unusually intense collection of man-made [[marine debris]], known as the [[Great Pacific garbage patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The North Pacific Subtropical Gyre and the much smaller [[North Pacific Subpolar Gyre]] make up the two major gyre systems in the mid-latitudes of the Northern Pacific Ocean. This two-gyre circulation in the North Pacific is driven by the [[Trade winds|trade]] and [[Westerlies|westerly winds]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Descriptive Physical Oceanography: An Introduction|last=Talley|first=Lynne D.|last2=Pickard|first2=George L.|last3=Emery|first3=William J.|last4=Swift|first4=James H.|publisher=Academic Press|year=2011|isbn=0750645520|location=London, UK|pages=}}</ref> This is one of the best examples of all of Earth’s oceans where these winds drive a two-gyre circulation. Physical characteristics like weak [[thermohaline circulation]] in the North Pacific and it is mostly blocked by land in the north, also help facilitate this circulation. As depth increases, these gyres in the North Pacific grow smaller and weaker, and the [[High-pressure area|high pressure]] at the center of the Subtropical Gyre will migrate poleward and westward.<ref name=":0" />
== Physical oceanography ==
=== Subtropical circulation in the North Pacific ===
Like all subtropical gyre systems, the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre is an [[anticyclone]] meaning the circulation is in a clockwise direction around its high pressure at the center because of its placement in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. This circulation is also associated with equatorward [[Sverdrup balance|Sverdrup]] transport and [[Ekman transport|Ekman]] downwelling.<ref name=":0" /> Ekman transport causes water to flow toward the center of the gyre, creating a sloped sea-surface, and initiating [[Geostrophic wind#geostrophic flow|geostrophic flow]]. [[Harald Sverdrup (oceanographer)|Harald Sverdrup]] applied Ekman transport while including pressure gradient forces to develop a theory for Sverdrup transport.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Introductory Dynamical Oceanography|last=Pond, S.|first=|last2=Pickard, G. L.|publisher=Pergamon Press|year=1983|isbn=978-0-08-028728-7|location=|pages=}}</ref>
The [[Kuroshio Current]] is the narrow, strong westward boundary current of the subtropical circulation. This current influences the water column all the way to the bottom. The Kuroshio current flows in a northerly direction, then eventually flows further from the westward boundary where it then takes an eastward direction into the North Pacific. This eastward flowing current is then called the Kuroshio Extension. The [[North Pacific Current]] is located just north of the Subtropical Gyre and flows in an easterly direction. Also, known as the West Wind Drift or the Subarctic Current, the North Pacific Current also includes the westward flow of the southern boundary of the North Pacific Subpolar Gyre.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Oceans: Their Physics, Chemistry, and General Biology|last=Sverdrup|first=H. U.|last2=Johnson|first2=|last3=Fleming|first3=R. H.|publisher=Prentice-Hall|year=1942|isbn=|location=New York|pages=M. W.}}</ref> The [[North Equatorial Current]] borders the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre on the south and flows in a westerly direction. The westward flow within the elongated tropical [[Cyclone|cyclonic]] circulation is also included in the North Equatorial current. The [[California Current|California Current System]] comprises the eastern boundary of the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre and flows south along the coast of California. Here [[Upwelling|coastal upwelling]] drives the eastern boundary current and an undercurrent that flows poleward.
In the western region of the North Pacific, the surface of the Subtropical Gyre generally has a "C-shape".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wyrki|first=K.|date=1975|title=Fluctuations of the Dynamic Topography of the Pacific Ocean|url=|journal=Journal of Physical Oceanography|volume=5 | issue = 3 |pages=450–459|doi=10.1175/1520-0485(1975)005<0450:fotdti>2.0.co;2}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasunuma|first=K.|last2=Yoshida|first2=K.|date=1978|title=Splitting of the subtropical gyre in the western North Pacific|url=|journal=Journal of Oceanography|volume=34 | issue = 4 |pages=160–172|doi=10.1007/bf02108654}}</ref> The Kuroshio current and Kuroshio Extension roughly from the outside of this "C-shape" where it then turns westwards into recirculation, where it then flows south parallel to the Kuroshio Current. From here the "C-shape" then flows eastward comprising the [[Subtropical Countercurrent]] at roughly 20 – 25⁰N, then finally the "C" wraps back towards the west forming the North Equatorial Current just south of 20⁰N. It is common for subtropical gyres to have this "C-shape" surface flow. The Subtropical Countercurrent is a shallow area of this "C"; at only about 250 dbar under the surface, circulation is a simpler closed, anticyclonic gyre.
Narrow east-west frontal zones that cross the Pacific are less than 100  km wide. The Subarctic Frontal Zone or Subarctic Boundary, about 42⁰N, is fixed in the North Pacific Current.<ref name=":0" /> The Subarctic Frontal Zone, slightly south of the maximum westerly wind speeds, separates the North Pacific Subpolar Gyre from the Subtropical Gyre. In the central and eastern Pacific at roughly 32⁰N is the Subtropical Frontal Zone. Sometimes referred to as the Subtropical Convergence Zone, this frontal zone serves as the boundary between the west flowing North Equatorial Current from the North Pacific Current.<ref name=":0" /> With increasing depth in the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre, it gets smaller in the western region near Japan and it also loses strength. The Subtropical Gyre does not exist below 1500 m below the surface with the exception of the Kuroshio Current and Extension regions.
==== Circulation dependence on depth ====
The North Pacific Subtropical Gyre diminishes spatially with increasing depth. Similar to all subtropical gyre systems, the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre shrinks towards its most energetic surface flows, in a northwestern direction between the Kuroshio Current and the Kuroshio Extension. This is drastic shrinkage from the surface to about 200 m below.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Reid|first=J. L.|date=1997|title=On the Total Geostrophic Circulation of the Pacific Ocean: Flow Patterns, Tracers, and Transports|url=|journal=Progress in Oceanography|volume=39 | issue = 4 |pages=263–352|doi=10.1016/s0079-6611(97)00012-8|bibcode=1997PrOce..39..263R}}</ref> At the surface, the boundary that separates the westward and eastward flows from south of 20⁰N to about 25 – 30⁰N at 200 m. The "C-shape" in the western region of the Subtropical Gyre, including the Subtropical Countercurrent, generally does not exist below 200 m. At about 1000 – 1500 m, the Subtropical Gyre is located entirely in the western region of the North Pacific near the Kuroshio Current and Kuroshio Extension.<ref name=":1" /> In the subtropical regions, flow is weak where influences from the Subtropical Gyre are minimal. Differences in steric heights over distances of 1000  km are on the order of 1  cm, rather than the differences of 10  cm within the area of the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre.

{{Global surveillance}}
The '''origins of [[global surveillance]]''' can be traced back to the late 1940s, when the [[UKUSA Agreement]] was jointly enacted by the United Kingdom and the United States, whose close cooperation eventually culminated in the creation of the global surveillance network, code-named "'''[[ECHELON]]'''", in 1971.<ref>{{cite news|title=Q&A: What you need to know about Echelon|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/1357513.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=29 May 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Nabbali|first=Talitha|author2=Perry, Mark|title=Going for the throat|journal=Computer Law & Security Review|date=March 2004|volume=20|issue=2|pages=84–97|doi=10.1016/S0267-3649(04)00018-4|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0267364904000184|quote=It wasn't until 1971 that the UKUSA allies began ECHELON}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[Watergate scandal|1970s Watergate affair]] and a subsequent [[congressional inquiry]] led by Sen. [[Frank Church]],<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/homefront/preemption/telecoms.html Pre-Emption - The Nsa And The Telecoms | Spying On The Home Front | FRONTLINE | PBS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> it was revealed that the NSA, in collaboration with Britain's GCHQ, had routinely intercepted the international communications of prominent anti-[[Vietnam War]] leaders such as [[Jane Fonda]] and Dr. [[Benjamin Spock]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Cohen |first=Martin |title=No Holiday |url= |location=New York |publisher=Disinformation Company Ltd |isbn=978-1-932857-29-0}}</ref> Decades later, a multi-year investigation by the [[European Parliament]] highlighted the NSA's role in [[Industrial espionage|economic espionage]] in a report entitled 'Development of Surveillance Technology and Risk of Abuse of Economic Information', in 1999.<ref>{{Cite report |author=Peggy Becker |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=October 1999 |title=DEVELOPMENT OF SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGY AND RISK OF ABUSE OF ECONOMIC INFORMATION |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/stoa/cms/cache/offonce/home/publications/studies?page=12 |publisher=STOA, European Parliament |page= |docket= |accessdate=November 3, 2013 |quote= }}</ref>
However, for the general public, it was a series of detailed disclosures of internal NSA documents in June 2013 that first revealed the massive extent of the NSA's spying, both foreign and domestic. Most of these were leaked by an ex-contractor, [[Edward Snowden]]. Even so, a number of these older global surveillance programs such as [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], [[XKeyscore]], and [[Tempora]] were referenced in the 2013 release of thousands of documents.<ref>[http://tv.msnbc.com/2013/07/15/snowden-has-thousands-of-damaging-nsa-documents-says-greenwald/ Snowden has ‘thousands’ of damaging NSA documents, says Greenwald]</ref> As confirmed by the NSA's director [[Keith B. Alexander]] on September 26, 2013, the NSA collects and stores all phone records of all American citizens.<ref>{{cite news|title=Senators: Limit NSA snooping into US phone records|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/senators-limit-nsa-snooping-us-phone-records|work=Associated Press|accessdate=October 15, 2013|quote="Is it the goal of the NSA to collect the phone records of all Americans?" Udall asked at Thursday's hearing. "Yes, I believe it is in the nation's best interest to put all the phone records into a lockbox that we could search when the nation needs to do it. Yes," Alexander replied.}}</ref> Much of the data is kept in large storage facilities such as the [[Utah Data Center]], a US$1.5 billion [[megaproject]] referred to by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' as a "symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess."<ref>{{cite news|last=Siobhan Gorman|title=Meltdowns Hobble NSA Data Center|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304441404579119490744478398|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=October 19, 2013|quote=The Utah facility, one of the Pentagon's biggest U.S. construction projects, has become a symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess, which gained broad attention in the wake of leaks from NSA contractor Edward Snowden.}}</ref>
== Clandestine surveillance in the United States == {{Main article|Mass surveillance in the United States}}
[[File:Albert Einstein Head.jpg|thumb|200px|Due to his alleged ties to [[communism]], the German-born physicist [[Albert Einstein]] was placed under surveillance by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) shortly after he [[emigration|emigrated]] to America. The FBI [[mail cover|monitored Einstein's mail]], [[phone bug|intercepted his telephone calls]], and searched his trash.<ref name="einsteinnytimes"/>]] [[File:Muhammad Ali NYWTS.jpg|thumb|200px|The American boxer [[Muhammad Ali]], a self-declared [[Vietnam War]] conscientious objector, was targeted by the NSA's [[Project MINARET]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Ryan Gallagher|title=Documents Show the NSA Spied on Muhammad Ali, Martin Luther King Jr., and ... Art Buchwald|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/09/26/minaret_nsa_surveillance_program_spied_on_muhammad_ali_martin_luther_king.html|publisher=''[[Slate (magazine)]]''|date=2002-05-07|accessdate=October 27, 2013}}</ref>]]
Wartime censorship of communications during the World Wars was paralleled by peacetime decipherment of communications by the [[Black Chamber]] (Cipher Bureau, MI-8), operating with the approval of the [[U.S. State Department]] from 1919 to 1929.<ref name="reutershistory">{{cite news|title=Factbox: History of mass surveillance in the United States|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/07/us-usa-security-records-factbox-idUSBRE95617O20130607|agency=Reuters|accessdate=August 14, 2013|date=June 7, 2013}}</ref> In 1945 the now-defunct [[Project SHAMROCK]] was created to gather all [[telegraph]]ic data entering into or exiting from the United States.<ref name="reutershistory"/><ref>{{cite web |last=The Center for Cryptologic History |url=http://www.nsa.gov/publications/publi00015.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040318034627/http://www.nsa.gov/publications/publi00015.cfm |archivedate=March 18, 2004 |title=The Origins of NSA (NSA.gov) |publisher=Web.archive.org}}</ref> Major communication companies such as [[Western Union]], [[RCA|RCA Global]] and [[ITT Corporation|ITT World Communications]] actively aided the U.S. government in the latter's attempt to gain access to international message traffic.<ref name="pbs">{{cite web|last1=Epsley-Jones |first1=Katelyn |first2=Christina |last2=Frenzel|title=The Church Committee Hearings & the FISA Court |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/homefront/preemption/churchfisa.html |publisher=PBS |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
In 1952, the NSA was officially established.<ref name="reutershistory"/> According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the NSA was created in "absolute secrecy" by [[Harry Truman|President Truman]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bamford |first=James |title=The Agency That Could Be Big Brother|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/25/weekinreview/25bamford.html?pagewanted=print|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 14, 2013 |date=December 25, 2005}}</ref> Six weeks after President Truman took office, he ordered [[Telephone tapping|wiretaps]] on the telephones of [[Thomas Gardiner Corcoran]], a close advisor of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]].<ref>{{cite news|last=DAVID BURNHAM|title=TRUMAN WIRETAPS ON EX-NEW DEAL AIDE CITED|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/02/01/us/truman-wiretaps-on-ex-new-deal-aide-cited.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=February 1, 1986}}</ref> The recorded conversations are currently kept at the [[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum]], along with other sensitive documents ([http://www.trumanlibrary.org/hstpaper/psf.htm ~233,600 pages]).
Under [[J. Edgar Hoover]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) carried out wide-ranging surveillance of communications and political expression, targeting many well-known speakers such as [[Albert Einstein]],<ref name="einsteinnytimes">{{cite news|title=New Details Emerge From the Einstein Files; How the F.B.I. Tracked His Phone Calls and His Trash|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/07/science/new-details-emerge-einstein-files-fbi-tracked-his-phone-calls-his-trash.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=September 17, 2013|first=Dennis|last=Overbye|date=May 7, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=FBI campaign against Einstein revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/2033324.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=June 8, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Albert Einstein: Fact or Fiction?|url=http://www.history.com/topics/einsteins-life-facts-and-fiction|publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=Because of his controversial political beliefs-his support for socialism, civil rights, and nuclear disarmament, for example-many anti-Communist crusaders believed that Einstein was a dangerous subversive. Some, like FBI director J. Edgar Hoover, even thought he was a spy. For 22 years, Hoover's agents tapped Einstein's phones, opened his mail, rifled through his trash and even bugged his secretary's nephew's house, all to prove that he was more radical (as his 1,500-page FBI dossier noted) than "even Stalin himself."}}</ref> [[Frank Sinatra]],<ref>{{cite news|last=RONALD J. OSTROW and LISA GETTER|title=FBI Files on Sinatra Detail Links to JFK, Mob Figures|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/dec/09/news/mn-52274|publisher=''Los Angeles Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=December 9, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=MOLOTSKY|first=IRVIN|title=F.B.I. Releases Its Sinatra File, With Tidbits Old and New|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/us/fbi-releases-its-sinatra-file-with-tidbits-old-and-new.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=December 9, 1998}}</ref> First Lady [[Eleanor Roosevelt]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Question: Why is Eleanor Roosevelt's FBI file so large?|url=http://www.gwu.edu/~erpapers/teachinger/q-and-a/q31.cfm|publisher=[[George Washington University]]|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Eleanor Roosevelt|url=http://www.history.com/topics/eleanor-roosevelt|publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)]]|accessdate=September 18, 2013|quote=J. Edgar Hoover (1895–1972), the longtime director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, considered Eleanor Roosevelt’s liberal views dangerous and believed she might be involved in communist activities. He ordered his agents to monitor Roosevelt and keep what became an extensive file on her.}}</ref> [[Marilyn Monroe]],<ref name="apmonroe">{{cite news|title=FBI removes many redactions in Marilyn Monroe file|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/fbi-removes-many-redactions-marilyn-monroe-file|work=Associated Press|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref> [[John Lennon]],<ref name="nytimesbeatles">{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Adam|title=While Nixon Campaigned, the F.B.I. Watched John Lennon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/21/opinion/21thu4.html|publisher=''The New York Times''|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=September 21, 2006}}</ref> [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Martin Luther King, Jr. FBI File|url=http://library.truman.edu/microforms/martin_luther_king.asp|publisher=Pickler Memorial Library ([[Truman State University]])|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Church>{{citation|last=Church|first= Frank|authorlink= Frank Church|title= Church Committee Book III| work =Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Case Study| publisher= [[Church Committee]]| date=April 23, 1976}}</ref> A FBI memo recognized King to be the "most dangerous and effective [[Negro]] leader in the country.",<ref name="mlkcommunism">{{cite news|title=FBI tracked King's every move|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/US/03/31/mlk.fbi.conspiracy/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=December 29, 2008}}</ref> and [[Daniel Ellsberg]],<ref>{{cite web|title='Life Lessons' From a White House Plumber|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=14468307|publisher=[[NPR]]|quote=When Daniel Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers to The New York Times in 1971, the Nixon White House tried to discredit him. Among other things, Nixon loyalists burglarized the office of Ellsberg's psychiatrist.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Watergate Story|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/watergate/timeline.html|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=The White House "plumbers" unit - named for their orders to plug leaks in the administration - burglarizes a psychiatrist's office to find files on Daniel Ellsberg, the former defense analyst who leaked the Pentagon Papers.}}</ref> Some of these activities were eventually uncovered in the aftermath of the [[Watergate scandal]], leading to the [[Resignation of Richard Nixon]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Watergate and the Constitution|url=https://www.archives.gov/education/lessons/watergate-constitution/|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}</ref>
{{Quotation| '''INVESTIGATIONS: Nobody Asked: Is It Moral?'''
''It did not matter that much of the information had already been released —or leaked—to the public. The effect was still overwhelming: a stunning, dismaying [[indictment]] of U.S. [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]] and six [[President of the United States|Presidents]], from [[Franklin Roosevelt]] to [[Richard Nixon]], for having blithely violated [[Democracy|democratic ideal]]s and [[Human rights|individual rights]] while gathering information at home or conducting [[clandestine operation]]s abroad...''
|'''''[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]'', May 10, 1976'''<ref>{{cite news|title=INVESTIGATIONS: Nobody Asked: Is It Moral?|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,914164,00.html|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|date=May 10, 1976}}</ref> }}
== Mass surveillance in a global context (1940–2001) == {{Main article|ECHELON}}
[[File:Mandela voting in 1994.jpg|thumb|200px|South Africa's anti-[[apartheid]] President [[Nelson Mandela]] was closely watched by British [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] agents.<ref>{{cite news|title=British intelligence 'birdwatchers spied on Nelson Mandela's hideout'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/nelson-mandela/10169630/British-intelligence-birdwatchers-spied-on-Nelson-Mandelas-hideout.html|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|accessdate=September 21, 2013|location=London|first=Aislinn|last=Laing|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nelson Mandela ‘was spied on by MI6 birdwatchers’|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/africa/article3812361.ece|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|accessdate=September 21, 2013}}</ref>]] [[File:Diana, Princess of Wales 1997 (2).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]]'s phone calls were monitored and recorded by the NSA right until she died in a 1997 [[Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|Paris car crash]].<ref>{{cite news|title=NSA Admits to Spying on Princess Diana|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/daily/dec98/diana12.htm|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=September 21, 2013|date=December 12, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=David Hencke and Rob Evans|title=US holds secret files on Diana|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/aug/06/monarchy.freedomofinformation|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 6, 1999}}</ref>]]
During World War II the U.K. and U.S. governments entered into a series of agreements for sharing of [[signals intelligence]] of enemy communications traffic.<ref name="BRUSA papers">U.S. National Security Agency. [http://www.nsa.gov/public_info/_files/ukusa/early_papers_1940-1944.pdf Early Papers Concerning US-UK Agreement – 1940–1944] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918015422/http://www.nsa.gov/public_info/_files/ukusa/early_papers_1940-1944.pdf |date=September 18, 2013}}. Agreement between British Government Code and Cipher School and U.S. War Department dated May 17, 1943. Retrieved: October 5, 2013.</ref> In March 1946, a secret agreement, the "[[1943 BRUSA Agreement|British-US Communication Intelligence Agreement]]", known as BRUSA, was established, based on the wartime agreements. The agreement "tied the two countries into a worldwide network of listening posts run by [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ), the U.K.'s biggest spying organisation, and its U.S. equivalent, the National Security Agency."<ref name="Guardian 2010">{{cite news|last=Norton-Taylor|first=Richard|title=Not so secret: deal at the heart of UK-US intelligence|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/25/intelligence-deal-uk-us-released|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 25, 2010|accessdate=June 25, 2010|location=London}}</ref>
In 1988, an article titled "Somebody's listening" by [[Duncan Campbell (journalist)|Duncan Campbell]] in the ''[[New Statesman]]'', described the signals intelligence gathering activities of a program code-named "[[ECHELON]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Campbell |first=Duncan |authorlink=Duncan Campbell (journalist) |title=Somebody's Listening |newspaper=[[New Statesman]] |date=August 12, 1988 |url=http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103071501/http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |archivedate=January 3, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2013}}</ref> The program was engaged by English-speaking World War II [[Allies of World War II|Allied powers]] Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States (collectively known as [[AUSCANNZUKUS]]). Based on the [[UKUSA Agreement]], it was created to monitor the military and diplomatic communications of the [[Soviet Union]] and its [[Eastern Bloc]] allies during the [[Cold War]] in the early 1960s.<ref name = EP>{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//NONSGML+REPORT+A5-2001-0264+0+DOC+PDF+V0//EN&language=EN |title=On the existence of a global system for the interception of private and commercial communications (ECHELON interception system), (2001/2098(INI)) |last=Schmid |first=Gerhard |date=July 11, 2001 |format=PDF |page=194 |publisher=European Parliament: Temporary Committee on the ECHELON Interception System |accessdate=September 16, 2013}}</ref> Though its existence had long been known, the UKUSA agreement only became public in 2010. It enabled the U.S. and the U.K. to exchange "knowledge from operations involving intercepting, decoding and translating foreign communications." The agreement forbade the parties to reveal its existence to any third party.<ref name="Guardian 2010"/>
By the late 1990s the [[ECHELON]] system was capable of intercepting satellite transmissions, [[public switched telephone network]] (PSTN) communications (including most Internet traffic), and transmissions carried by microwave. A detailed description of ECHELON was provided by New Zealand journalist [[Nicky Hager]] in his 1996 book "Secret Power". While the existence of ECHELON was denied by some member governments, a report by a committee of the [[European Parliament]] in 2001 confirmed the program's use and warned Europeans about its reach and effects.<ref name="online.wsj.com">Fiddler, Stephen (July 1, 2013). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323936404578579811316559112 Echoes of Echelon in Charges of NSA Spying in Europe]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.</ref> The European Parliament stated in its report that the term "ECHELON" was used in a number of contexts, but that the evidence presented indicated it was a signals intelligence collection system capable of interception and content inspection of telephone calls, fax, e-mail and other data traffic globally. The report to the European Parliament confirmed that this was a "global system for the interception of private and commercial communications."<ref name=EP/>
{{Quotation |'''Echelon spy network revealed'''
'' Imagine a global spying network that can eavesdrop on every single [[phone call]], [[fax]] or [[e-mail]], anywhere on the planet. It sounds like science fiction, but it's true. Two of the chief protagonists - [[UKUSA Agreement|Britain and America]] - officially deny its existence. But the [[BBC]] has confirmation from the [[Australian Government]] that such a network really does exist..."''
|'''The British Broadcasting Corporation ([[BBC]]), November 1999'''<ref>{{cite news|last=Andrew Bomford|title=Echelon spy network revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/503224.stm|publisher=BBC|date=November 3, 1999}}</ref> }}
== 9/11 and its implications on global surveillance (2001–2009) == {{Further information|NSA warrantless surveillance (2001–07)}}
[[File:Kofi Annan.jpg|thumb|200px|The 7th U.N. Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] was placed under surveillance by British intelligence agents, who bugged his office in the lead up to the [[Iraq War]].<ref>{{cite news|title=UK 'spied on UN's Kofi Annan'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/3488548.stm|publisher=BBC|date=February 2004}}</ref>]] [[File:Ban Ki-moon headshot.jpg|thumb|200px|The 8th U.N. Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] was placed under surveillance by U.S. diplomats, who also collected [[Iris recognition|iris scan]]s, [[fingerprint]]s and [[DNA]] of foreign diplomats, according to leaked documents released by [[WikiLeaks]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Paul Richter and Ken Dilanian|title=U.S. diplomats ordered to gather data on counterparts, WikiLeaks releases show|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/nov/29/world/la-fg-1129-wikileaks-20101129|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=17 December 2013|date=November 29, 2010}}</ref><ref name="clintonbankimoon">{{cite web|title=US diplomats spied on UN leadership |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/28/us-embassy-cables-spying-un|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=August 27, 2013}}</ref>]] In the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001 on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] and [[the Pentagon]], the scope of domestic spying in the United States increased significantly. The bid to prevent future attacks of this scale led to the passage of the [[Patriot Act]]. Later acts include the [[Protect America Act]] (which removes the warrant requirement for government surveillance of foreign targets<ref name="Judiciary Testimony">{{cite web |date=September 18, 2007 |title=Warrantless Surveillance and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act: The Role of Checks and Balances in Protecting Americans' Privacy Rights (Part II): Hearing Before the H. Comm. on the Judiciary, 110th Cong. 13–30 (statement of J.M. McConnell, Director of National Intelligence) |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-110hhrg37844/pdf/CHRG-110hhrg37844.pdf}}</ref>) and the [[FISA Amendments Act]] (which relaxed some of the original FISA court requirements).
In 2005, the existence of [[STELLARWIND]] was revealed by [[Thomas Tamm]]. On January 1, 2006, days after ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that "''Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts'',<ref name="nytimes123">{{cite news |last1=Risen |first1=James |last2=Lichtblau |first2=Eric |title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/16program.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|quote=The White House asked The New York Times not to publish this article |accessdate=August 14, 2013 |date=December 16, 2005}}</ref> the President emphasized that "''This is a limited program designed to prevent attacks on the United States of America. And I repeat, limited.''"<ref name="White House">{{cite web |date=January 1, 2006 <!-- , 12:05 PM CST --> |title=President Visits Troops at Brooke Army Medical Center |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/01/20060101.html |publisher=White House|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref>
In 2006, [[Mark Klein]] revealed the existence of [[Room 641A]] that he had wired back in 2003.<ref name=WiredEvidence>{{cite journal |url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/05/70908 |title=AT&T Whistle-Blower's Evidence |journal=Wired |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref> In 2008, Babak Pasdar, a computer security expert, and CEO of [[Bat Blue]] publicly revealed the existence of the "Quantico circuit", that he and his team found in 2003. He described it as a back door to the federal government in the systems of an unnamed wireless provider; the company was later independently identified as [[Verizon]].<ref name="Poulsen">{{cite news|last=Poulsen|first=Kevin|title=Whistle-Blower: Feds Have a Backdoor Into Wireless Carrier — Congress Reacts|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2008/03/whistleblower-f/|work=Wired|accessdate=August 14, 2013|date=March 6, 2008}}</ref> Additional disclosures regarding a mass surveillance program involving U.S. citizens had been made in the U.S. media in 2006.<ref name="usatoday2006">{{cite news |last1=Cauley |first=Leslie |title=NSA has massive database of Americans' phone calls |url=http://yahoo.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm |work=USA Today |date=May 11, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130713213322/http://yahoo.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm |archivedate=July 13, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
{{Quotation |'''You Are a Suspect''' ''Every purchase you make with a [[credit card]], every [[magazine]] [[Subscription business model|subscription]] you buy and [[medical prescription]] you fill, every Web site you visit and [[e-mail]] you send or receive, every [[Academic grading in the United States|academic grade]] you receive, every [[Deposit account|bank deposit]] you make, every trip you book and every event you attend—all these transactions and communications will go into what the [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]] describes as a virtual, centralized grand database. To this computerized dossier on your private life from commercial sources, add every piece of information that government has about you—[[passport]] application, [[driver's license]] and [[Toll bridge|toll records]], judicial and [[divorce]] records, complaints from nosy neighbors to the F.B.I., your lifetime paper trail plus the latest hidden camera surveillance—and you have the supersnoop's dream: a [[Total Information Awareness]] about every U.S. citizen.''
|'''''[[The New York Times]]'', November 2002'''<ref>{{cite news|author=William Safire|title=You Are a Suspect|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/14/opinion/you-are-a-suspect.html |work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 20, 2013|date=November 14, 2002}}</ref> |qalign = left }}
== Acceleration of media leaks (2010–present) == On November 28, 2010, [[WikiLeaks]] and five major news outlets in Spain (''[[El País]]''), France (''[[Le Monde]]''), Germany (''[[Der Spiegel]]''), the United Kingdom (''[[The Guardian]]''), and the United States (''[[The New York Times]]'') began publishing the first 220 of 251,287 leaked [[United States diplomatic cables leak|U.S. State department diplomatic "cables"]] simultaneously.<ref>{{cite web|title=WikiLeaks FAQ: What Do the Diplomatic Cables Really Tell Us?|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/wikileaks-faq-what-do-the-diplomatic-cables-really-tell-us-a-731441.html|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
On March 15, 2012, the American magazine ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' published an article with the headline "The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)",<ref name="wired11">{{cite news|title=The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1|work=Wired|accessdate=August 14, 2013|first=James|last=Bamford|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref> which was later mentioned by U.S. Rep. [[Hank Johnson]] during a congressional hearing. In response to Johnson's inquiry, NSA director [[Keith B. Alexander]] testified that these allegations made by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine were untrue.<ref name="forbes1">{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|title=NSA Chief Denies Wired's Domestic Spying Story (Fourteen Times) In Congressional Hearing|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2012/03/20/nsa-chief-denies-wireds-domestic-spying-story-fourteen-times-in-congressional-hearing/|work=Forbes|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
In early 2013, [[Edward Snowden]] handed over 200,000 [[top secret]] documents to various media outlets, triggering one of the biggest [[news leak]]s in the modern [[history of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-CIA employee source of leak on PRISM program|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130609-former-cia-employee-source-us-intelligence-leaks-snowden-nsa|publisher=[[France 24]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|quote=Snowden’s decision to reveal his identity and whereabouts lifts the lid on one of the biggest security leaks in US history and escalates a story that has placed a bright light on Obama’s extensive use of secret surveillance.}}</ref>
== See also == * [[History of surveillance]]
== References == <references/>
[[Category:Global surveillance]]

{{short description|A cold subarctic ocean current that flows south and circulates counterclockwise in the western North Pacific Ocean}} [[File:Spring Bloom Colors the Pacific Near Hokkaido.jpg|thumb|The Oyashio Current colliding with the [[Kuroshio Current]] near [[Hokkaido]]. When two currents collide, they create [[Eddy (fluid dynamics)|eddies]]. [[Phytoplankton]] growing in the surface waters become concentrated along the boundaries of these eddies, tracing out the motions of the water.]] [[File:Japan's ocean currents.PNG|thumb|The ocean currents surrounding the Japanese Archipelago: 1.[[Kuroshio]] 2. Kuroshio extension 3. Kuroshio countercurrent 4. The Tsushima Current 5. The Tsugaru Current 6. The Sōya Current '''7. Oyashio''' 8. [[:ja:リマン海流|The Liman Current]] ]]
{{nihongo|'''Oyashio'''|親潮||"Parental Tide"}}, also known as '''Oya Siwo''', '''Okhotsk''' or the '''[[Kuril Islands|Kurile]] current''', is a cold [[subarctic]] [[ocean current]] that flows south and circulates counterclockwise in the western North [[Pacific Ocean]]. The waters of the Oyashio Current originate in the [[Arctic Ocean]] and flow southward via the [[Bering Sea]], passing through the Bering Strait and transporting cold water from the Arctic Sea into the Pacific Ocean and the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]. It collides with the [[Kuroshio Current]] off the eastern shore of [[Japan]] to form the [[North Pacific Current]] (or Drift). The nutrient-rich Oyashio is named for its metaphorical role as the {{nihongo|parent|親|''oya''}} that provides for and nurtures marine organisms.<ref>{{cite book|chapter= Kuroshio and Oyashio Currents|date=2001|last=Qiu|first=Bo|title=Encyclopedia of Ocean Sciences|page=1413–25| publisher=Academic Press | url=http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/oceanography/bo/Q01.pdf |quote= The upwelled, nutrient-rich water feeds the Oyashio from the north and leads to its nomenclature, parent (''oya'') stream (''shio'').}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Glattstein|first=Judy|title=Enhance Your Garden with Japanese Plants|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BAhIAAAAYAAJ|year=1996|publisher=Kodansha International|isbn=978-1-56836-137-6|page=16 |quote=[...] currents whirl around and ascend, and nourish microscopic plankton. Oyashio is thus the parent of fishes.}}</ref>
The current has an important impact on the climate of the [[Russian Far East]], mainly in [[Kamchatka Peninsula|Kamchatka]] and [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]], where the northern [[tree line|limit of tree growth]] is moved south up to ten degrees compared with the latitude it can reach in inland [[Siberia]]. The waters of the Oyashio Current form probably the richest [[fishery]] in the world owing to the extremely high-nutrient content of the cold water and the very high [[tides]] (up to ten metres) in some areas – which further enhances the availability of nutrients. However, the Oyashio Current also causes [[Vladivostok]] to be the most equatorward [[port]] to seasonally freeze and require [[icebreaker|icebreaking ships]] to remain open in winter. Nonetheless, this has relatively little effect on the fish yield through the Sea of Okhotsk, because the large tides mean freezing does not occur so easily.
During [[glacial period]]s, when lower [[sea level]] exposed the [[Bering land bridge]], the current could not flow in the regions the Oyashio affects today. The level of cooling with the onset of glacial conditions (after an [[interglacial]]) was much less than in other areas of the Earth at similar latitudes. This allowed [[Tōhoku Region|Tōhoku]] and [[Hokkaidō]] – the only areas of [[East Asia]] with enough snowfall to potentially form glaciers – to remain unglaciated except at high elevations during periods when Europe and [[North America]] were largely glaciated. This lack of glaciation explains why, despite its present climate being much colder than most of [[Europe]], East Asia has retained 96 percent of [[Pliocene]] tree genera, whereas Europe has retained only 27%.{{cn|date=August 2017}}
== See also == * [[Ocean current]] * [[Oceanic gyres]] * [[Physical oceanography]] * {{ship|Japanese destroyer|Oyashio}}, the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] destroyer named after the current.
==References== {{reflist}} *Reddy, MPM (2001): ''Descriptive physical oceanography''. Taylor and Francis, {{ISBN|90-5410-706-5}}, pp 367–8.

revision.text:
[[Image:Panjal Traps.jpg|thumb|Panjal Traps in 1912]] The '''Panjal Traps''' or the '''Tethyan Plume''' is a [[large igneous province]] (LIP) that erupted during the Early–Middle [[Permian]] in what is now north-western [[India]]. The Panjal Traps are associated with the opening of the [[Tethys Ocean|Neo-Tethys Ocean]], which resulted in the dispersal of the [[Cimmeria (continent)|Cimmerian]] [[continental fragment|continental blocks]] from the north-eastern margin of [[Gondwana]] and possibly the break-up of this old and large continent.<ref>{{Harvnb|Chauvet|Lapierre|Bosch|Guillot|2008|loc=Introduction, p. 384}}</ref> In the [[Zanskar]]-[[Lahaul and Spiti district|Spliti-Lahaul]] area (in the north-western Himalayas and south-east Ladakh) the {{Convert|30|-|150|m|abbr=on}}-thick basalts of the Panjal Traps are mostly exposed as massive (terrestrial) lava flows, but also as (marine) [[pillow lava]]s and [[hyaloclastite]]s.<ref name="Chauvet-setting">{{Harvnb|Chauvet|Lapierre|Bosch|Guillot|2008|loc=Geological setting, pp. 384–386}}</ref>
The Panjal Traps were first documented in 1824 and were eventually named by British geologist [[Richard Lydekker]] in 1883,<ref>{{Harvnb|Lydekker|1883}}</ref> but their origin, age, and relationship with surrounding and underlying rocks remained elusive for more than a century.<ref name="Shellnutt-2014">{{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Wang|Brookfield|2014|loc=Introduction, pp. 159–161}}</ref> They remained one of the most understudied LIPs before being properly dated to 289 Ma in 2011.<ref name="Shellnutt-2011">{{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Brookfield|Jahn|2011|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
==Geological setting== Late Carboniferous to Early Permian deposits of Tethyan affinity in the Zanskar-Spiti area are mostly [[terrigenous]], [[Detritus|detrital]] sedimentary rocks, although some magmatic activity documented in Pakistan and central Nepal has been associated with this period. These sedimentary layers are associated with the erosion that followed the [[Tectonic uplift|uplift]] of the margins of the newly rifted Indian continent. In the eastern and central Himalayas more voluminous volcanic eruptions have been documented from the same period. The [[Abor Hills|Abor]] volcanics produced {{Convert|1500|m|abbr=on}} of [[basalt]]ic to [[andesite|andesitic]] flows and [[tuff]]s. In the Late Permian ([[Sakmarian]]-[[Roadian]]) the [[tholeiitic basalt|theoliitic]] [[Nar-Tsum]](?) produced {{Convert|300|m}} of [[spilite]]s and [[Bhote Koshi|Bhote Kosi]] basalts in southern Tibet.<ref name="Chauvet-setting" />
The slightly younger ([[Artinskian]]-[[Permian#anchor 2|Kazanian]]) Panjal Traps produced the largest magmatic province in north-western India. Its lava flows now covers 10<sup>5</sup> km<sup>2</sup>, from the eastern Zanskar-Spliti-Lahaul area to north-eastern Pakistan and they filled a rifted valley called the Zanskar-Spiti [[syncline|synclinorium]].<ref name="Chauvet-setting" /> The original extent of the Panjal Traps may have exceeded 0.2x10<sup>6</sup> km<sup>2</sup>, a distribution similar to those of the [[Emeishan Traps|Emeishan LIP]] in south-western China and the [[Columbia River Basalt Group|Columbia River basalts]] in north-western United States.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stojanovic|Aitchison|Ali|Ahmad|2016|loc=Introduction, p. 116}}</ref> In Ladakh and in the [[Kashmir Valley|Kashmir Basin]] the flows are {{Convert|2500|m|abbr=on}} thick with a smaller amount of [[pyroclastic]]s overlain by [[Phenocryst|aphyric]] basaltic flows. In north-eastern Pakistan the Panjal flows are exposed as [[Dike (geology)|dykes]] cross-cutting the [[Basement (geology)|basement]] and Early Paleozoic layers, and as inter-layered magmatic flows on Late Plaeozoic to Early Mesozoic layers with Tethyan affinity.<!--Panjal Traps are widespread and up to 2km thick under [[eclogite]]s and [[amphibolite]]s metamorphic [[facies]](?).--><ref name="Chauvet-setting" />
The eruption of the Panjal Traps was followed (Kazanian-[[Wuchiapingian|Djulfian]]) by the emplacement of a succession of sediments, the result of the progressive [[Thermal subsidence|thermo]]-[[tectonic subsidence]] of the Indian passive margin associated with the expanding Neo-Tethys.<ref name="Chauvet-setting" />
==Tectonic implications== The Panjal Traps have been associated with either the [[Olson's Extinction|Mid-Capitanian]] (260 Ma) or [[Permian–Triassic extinction event|End-Permian]] (251 Ma) mass extinction events. Analyses of zircon crystals have, however, yielded an [[U-Pb dating|<sup>206</sup>U/<sup>238</sup>Pb age]] of 289±2 Ma — considerably older than these mass extinctions.<ref name="Shellnutt-2011" /> The Panjal Traps can, nevertheless, be linked to the African [[Large low-shear-velocity provinces|large low-shear-velocity province]] (or superplume) and, as such, is most likely responsible for the widespread flood basalts in the Himalayas, but the [[Siberian Traps]] (251 Ma) are probably a better candidate for these younger mass extinctions.<ref>{{Harvnb|Torsvik|Cocks|2013|pp=1023–1024; Fig. 21, p. 1026}}</ref>
Late Carboniferous-Permian LIPs (such as [[Skagerrak-Centered Large Igneous Province|Jutland]], Panjal, [[Tarim Large Igenous Province|Tarim]], [[Emeishan Traps|Emeishan]] and Siberia) were emplaced before the break-up of Pangaea whereas the post-Permian LIPs were involved in the break-up of the supercontinent. Mantle plume-derived LIPs share features such as large-volume flood basalts, short duration, uplift and doming of the crust before eruption, and high temperature-melts such as [[komatiite]]s and [[picrite]]s.<ref name="Shellnutt-2014" /> The chemical and isotopic composition of samples of basalt taken from the eastern Kashmir Valley are similar to within-plate basalts, and probably derived from a [[spinel]] [[peridotite]] source. Samples taken from the western side of the valley are more primitive, derived from a more depleted source. This suggests that Panjal made a transition from a newly formed continental setting, where the basalt composition was 'enriched [[Ocean island basalt|OIB]]-like', to an old ocean basin, where the composition was 'depleted [[Mid-ocean ridge|MORB]]-like'. Chemically, the Panjal basalts are similar to those from post-Permian/post-Pangaean LIPs.<ref>{{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Wang|Yeh|2015|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
[[Paleomagnetism|Paleomagnetic]] data from the Kashmir Valley indicate the Panjal eruption occurred at a paleolatitude of c. 33° (±5°)S.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stojanovic|Aitchison|Ali|Ahmad|2016|loc=Abstract}}</ref>

G. | last2 = Bhat | first2 = G. M. | last3 = Brookfield | first3 = M. E. | last4 = Jahn | first4 = B. M. | title = No link between the Panjal Traps (Kashmir) and the Late Permian mass extinctions | year = 2011 | journal = Geophysical Research Letters | volume = 38 | issue = L19308 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/profile/G_Bhat/publication/251437233_No_link_between_the_Panjal_Traps_(Kashmir)_and_the_Late_Permian_mass_extinctions/links/00463536e5b13e5602000000.pdf | access-date = 23 July 2016 | doi = 10.1029/2011GL049032 | ref = harv | bibcode=2011GeoRL..3819308S}}<!-- {{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Brookfield|Jahn|2011}} --> * {{Cite journal | last1 = Shellnutt | first1 = J. G. | last2 = Bhat | first2 = G. M. | last3 = Wang | first3 = K. L. | last4 = Brookfield | first4 = M. E. | last5 = Jahn | first5 = B. M. | last6 = Dostal | first6 = J. | title = Petrogenesis of the flood basalts from the Early Permian Panjal Traps, Kashmir, India: Geochemical evidence for shallow melting of the mantle | year = 2014 | journal = Lithos | volume = 204 | pages = 159–171 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/profile/J_Shellnutt/publication/260032205_Petrogenesis_of_the_flood_basalts_from_the_Early_Permian_Panjal_Traps_Kashmir_India_Geochemical_evidence_for_shallow_melting_of_the_mantle/links/02e7e53508986aa113000000.pdf | access-date = 23 July 2016 | doi = 10.1016/j.lithos.2014.01.008 | ref = harv}}<!-- {{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Wang|Brookfield|2014}} --> * {{Cite journal | last1 = Shellnutt | first1 = J. G. | last2 = Bhat | first2 = G. M. | last3 = Wang | first3 = K. L. | last4 = Yeh | first4 = M. W. | last5 = Brookfield | first5 = M. E. | last6 = Jahn | first6 = B. M. | title = Multiple mantle sources of the Early Permian Panjal Traps, Kashmir, India | year = 2015 | journal = American Journal of Science | volume = 315 | issue = 7 | pages = 589–619 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/profile/J_Shellnutt/publication/280534350_Multiple_mantle_sources_of_the_Early_Permian_Panjal_Traps_Kashmir_India/links/55b841ab08aed621de05c442.pdf | access-date = 23 July 2016 | doi = 10.2475/07.2015.01 | ref = harv}}<!-- {{Harvnb|Shellnutt|Bhat|Wang|Yeh|2015}} --> * {{Cite journal | last1 = Stojanovic | first1 = D. | last2 = Aitchison | first2 = J.
