page.title: Peter's vision of a sheet with animals

revision.comment: σκεῦος does not have an extra accent unless followed by an enclitic.
revision.text:
{{Saint Peter}} [[File:Domenico Fetti 007.jpg|thumb|The vision painted by [[Domenico Fetti]].]] [[File:Peter's vision of the sheet with animals.jpg|thumb|right|Illustration from ''Treasures of the Bible'' by Henry Davenport Northrop, 1894.]] According to the [[Acts of the Apostles]], [[Acts 10|chapter 10]], [[Saint Peter]] had a vision of a vessel ({{Lang-el|σκεῦος}}, ''skeuos''; "a certain vessel descending upon him, as it had been a great sheet knit at the four corners") full of animals being lowered from [[Heaven (Christianity)|heaven]] ({{bibleref|Acts|10:11|KJV}}). A voice from heaven told Peter to kill and eat, but since the vessel (or sheet, ὀθόνη, ''othonē'') contained [[unclean animals]], Peter declined. The command was repeated two more times, along with the voice saying, "What God hath made clean, that call not thou common" (verse 15) and then the vessel was taken back to heaven (verse 16). At this point in the narrative, messengers sent from [[Cornelius the Centurion]] arrive and urge Peter to go with them. He does so, and mentions the vision as he speaks to Cornelius, saying "God hath shewed me that I should not call any man common or unclean" ({{bibleref|Acts|10:28|KJV}}). Peter related the vision again in {{bibleref|Acts|11:4-9|KJV}}. ==Interpretation== [[Simon J. Kistemaker]] suggests that the lesson God taught Peter in this vision is that "God has removed the barriers he once erected to separate his people from the surrounding nations."{{cite book|last=Kistemaker|first=Simon J. |authorlink=Simon J. Kistemaker|title=Exposition of the Acts of the Apostles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rascAAAACAAJ|year=1990|publisher=Baker Book House|isbn=978-0-8010-5290-3}}{{rp|378}} Kistemaker argues that it means Peter has to accept [[Gentile]] believers as full members of the [[Christian Church]], but also that God has made all animals clean, so that "Peter with his fellow [[Jewish Christian]]s can disregard the [[Kashrut|food laws]] that have been observed since the days of [[Moses]]."{{rp|380}} [[Albert Mohler]], President of Southern Seminary, writes:{{cite web| url= http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2012/05/21/my-take-the-bible-condemns-a-lot-but-heres-why-we-focus-on-homosexuality/ | title= The Bible condemns a lot, but here's why we focus on homosexuality| work= My Take| publisher= CNN | author=[[Albert Mohler|R. Albert Mohler Jr.]] | date= May 21, 2012 | accessdate=2012-05-21}}
As the Book of Acts makes clear, Christians are not obligated to follow this holiness code. This is made clear in Peter's vision in Acts 10:15. Peter is told, 'What God has made clean, do not call common.' In other words, there is no [[kosher]] code for Christians. Christians are not concerned with eating kosher foods and avoiding all others. That part of the law is no longer binding, and Christians can enjoy shrimp and pork with no injury to conscience.
[[Luke Timothy Johnson]] and [[Daniel J. Harrington]] write that this episode heralds a radical change in Peter's "identity as a member of God's people,"{{cite book|last1=Johnson|first1=Luke Timothy |authorlink1=Luke Timothy Johnson|last2=Harrington|first2=Daniel J. |authorlink2=Daniel J. Harrington|title=The Acts of the Apostles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oVLF53DjFPsC&pg=PA187|year=1992|publisher=Liturgical Press|location=Collegeville, MN|isbn=978-0-8146-5807-9}}{{rp|187-}} but also that "the implication is that all things God created are declared clean by him, and are not affected by human discriminations."{{rp|184}} On the other hand, the [[United Church of God]] (a group following the teachings of [[Herbert W. Armstrong]]) calls this an "often-misunderstood section of the Bible",{{cite book|title=What Does the Bible Teach About Clean and Unclean Meats?|year=2008|publisher=[[United Church of God]]|url=http://www.ucg.org/files/booklets/what-does-the-bible-teach-about-clean-and-unclean-meats.pdf|pages=12–13}} arguing that Peter's statement in verse 28 indicates that the divine disclosure reflected only a teaching about people, and not one about food. The UCG argues that Peter realised "the puzzling vision could not be annulling God’s instructions." The [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] has a similar view of this passage.{{cite book|title=Adventist Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i4_kAAAAMAAJ|date=January 2007|publisher=Review and Herald Pub. Association|volume=184 Pt 1|p=47}} Peter's triple refusal described in {{bibleref|Acts|10:16|KJV}} echoes the [[denial of Peter]] described in the [[Synoptic Gospels]].{{cite book|last=Witherington|first=Ben|authorlink=Ben Witherington III|title=The Acts of the Apostles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2P7zSnM9BjMC&pg=PA350|year=2008|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-4501-6|pp=350–}}{{cite book|last1=Rius-Camps|first1=Josep |last2=Read-Heimerdinger|first2=Jenny |title=The Message of Acts in Codex Bezae: A Comparison with the Alexandrian Tradition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jgGs0zlf71gC&pg=PA253|volume=Vol 2| year=2006| publisher=Continuum| isbn=978-0-567-04012-1| pages=253–}} ==Artistic depictions== Peter's vision was rarely shown in art, but has been illustrated with pen-and-ink drawings by [[Rembrandt]] and a variant by his pupil [[Samuel Dirksz van Hoogstraten|van Hoogstraten]]. Rembrandt was probably reacting to a painting of the subject by [[Domenico Fetti]] which was then in Amsterdam, and is now in [[Vienna]].{{cite book|last=Bevers|first=Holm |title=Drawings by Rembrandt and His Pupils: Telling the Difference|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQMBCBIJpCAC&pg=PA152|year=2009|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-978-2|pages=152–}} It also appears in the "Altar of St. Peter" in [[Seville Cathedral]], attributed to [[Francisco de Zurbarán]].{{cite journal|last1=Soria|first1=Martin S.|title=Zurbaráaan's Altar of Saint Peter|journal=The Art Bulletin|volume=33|issue=3|year=2015|pages=165–173|issn=0004-3079|doi=10.1080/00043079.1951.11408051}}{{cite book|last1=Réveil|first1=Etienne Achille |last2=Duchesne|first2=Jean |title=Museum of Painting and Sculpture: Or, Collection of the Principal Pictures, Statues and Bas-reliefs in the Public and Private Galleries of Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=byEUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PP364|year=1833|publisher=Bossange|pages=364–|volume=Vol 17}} ==References== {{Portal|Bible|Christianity}} {{reflist|30em}} {{Acts of the Apostles}} [[Category:Acts of the Apostles]] [[Category:Animals in the Bible]] [[Category:Biblical dreams and visions]] [[Category:Christian ethics in the Bible]] [[Category:Christian iconography]] [[Category:Kosher food]] [[Category:Saint Peter]]

{{Neogene}} The '''Piacenzian''' is in the international [[geologic time scale]] the upper [[stage (stratigraphy)|stage]] or latest [[age (geology)|age]] of the [[Pliocene]]. It spans the time between 3.6 ± 0.005 [[annum|Ma]] and 2.588 ± 0.005 Ma (million years ago). The Piacenzian is after the [[Zanclean]] and is followed by the [[Gelasian]] (part of the [[Pleistocene]]).
The Piacenzian is roughly [[coeval]] with the [[European land mammal age]] MN 16, overlaps the late [[Chapadmalalan]] and early [[Uquian]] [[South American land mammal age]] and falls inside the more extensive [[Blancan]] [[North American land mammal age]]. It also correlates with the Astian, Redonian, [[Reuverian]] and Romanian regional stages of Europe. Some authorities describe the British [[Red Crag Formation]] and Waltonian stage as late Piacenzian,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=RCG|title=Red Crag Formation|publisher=British Geological Survey|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://quaternary.stratigraphy.org/correlation/POSTERSTRAT_v2011.pdf.20110222-162627|title=Global Chronostratigraphical Correlation Table for the Last 2.7 Million Years. v.2011|publisher=University of Cambridge|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> while others regard them as early Pleistocene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004220.pdf |title=The Naze citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 5 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Michael|last=Allaby|title=Oxford Dictionary of Geology & Earth Sciences|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=626|year=2013|edition=4th|isbn=978-0-19-96530 6-5}}</ref>
==Definition== The Piacenzian was introduced in scientific literature by [[Switzerland|Swiss]] stratigrapher Karl Mayer-Eymar in 1858. It is named after the [[Italy|Italian]] city of [[Piacenza]].
The base of the Piacenzian is at the base of magnetic chronozone C2An (the base of the Gauss chronozone and at the [[extinction]] of the [[plankton]]ic [[foram]]s ''Globorotalia margaritae'' and ''Pulleniatina primalis''. The [[GSSP]] for the Piacenzian stage is at Punta Piccola on [[Sicily]], Italy.<ref>Castradori ''et al.'' (1998)</ref>
The top of the Piacenzian (the base of the Quaternary system and the Pleistocene series) is defined [[Magnetostratigraphy|magnetostratigraphically]] as the base of the Matuyama (C2r) [[chronozone]] (at the [[Gauss-Matuyama reversal]]), and isotopic stage 103. Above this point there are notable extinctions of the calcareous [[nanofossil]]s: ''[[Discoaster|Discoaster pentaradiatus]]'' and ''Discoaster surculus''.<ref>Gadstein ''et al.'' (2005), p. 28; Rio ''et al.'' (1998)</ref>
==Climate== Climate of the Piacenzian would have started as a somewhat wet and warm period in North America occurring just after a brief cooling period of the Zanclean. Deposition of sediments and mollusks of the Piacenzian correspond with the rise in sea level creating the Tamiami Subsea and Jackson Subsea of Florida, Duplin Subsea generally of [[South Carolina]], and Yorktown Subsea of the [[Outer Banks]] and inland [[North Carolina]]. Dates have been established on the basis of the genera and species of mollusks found.<ref>Petuch, Edward J., Ph.D. Florida Atlantic University, Department of Geodsciences. Cenozoic Seas: The View From Eastern North America. CRC Press, Dec. 29, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8493-1632-4}}.</ref>
==Origin of the genus ''Homo''== The late Piacenzian may be when the genus ''[[Homo]]'' developed out of the ancestral genus ''[[Australopithecus]]''.<ref name="bbc.first">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-31718336 |title='First human' discovered in Ethiopia |author=Pallab Ghosh|date=4 March 2015 |publisher=[[BBC]] |accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> While the oldest known fossils unambiguously identified as ''[[Homo habilis]]'' date to just after the end of the Piacenzian (2.58 Ma), a fossilized jawbone that exhibits traits that are transitional between ''Australopithecus'' and ''Homo habilis'' was discovered in the [[Afar Triangle]] in 2015. The find was made by Ethiopian student Chalachew Seyoum at a site called [[Ledi-Geraru]] between the [[Mille River|Mille]] and [[Awash River|Awash]] rivers, in [[Afar Region|Afar Regional State]] (near {{coord|11.36|N|40.86|E|}}).<ref name=newscientist>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn27079-oldest-known-member-of-human-family-found-in-ethiopia.html#.VPrw7vmsXId |title=Oldest known member of human family found in Ethiopia |publisher=''[[New Scientist]]'' |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ghosh |first=Pallab |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-31718336 |title= 'First human' discovered in Ethiopia |publisher=bbc.co.uk |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref> Based on geological evidence from the Afar region, the individual would have lived just after a major [[Abrupt climate change|climate shift]], during which forests and waterways were rapidly replaced by arid [[savanna]]. Regarding the Afar region, and as stated in the journal [[Science (journal)|''Science'']]: "Vertebrate fossils record a faunal turnover indicative of more open and probable arid habitats than those reconstructed earlier in this region, in broad agreement with hypotheses addressing the role of environmental forcing in hominin evolution at this time." This interpretation is consistent with hypotheses that emphasize the savanna as the [[Savanna principle|ancestral environment]] that shaped the evolution of early ''Homo'' and other hominins.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2015/03/03/science.aaa1415 |title=Late Pliocene fossiliferous sedimentary record and the environmental context of early ''Homo'' from Afar, Ethiopia |author1=Erin N. DiMaggio EN |author2=Campisano CJ |author3=Rowan J |author4=Dupont-Nivet G |author5=Deino AL |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |doi=10.1126/science.aaa1415 |display-authors=etal |pmid=25739409 |volume=347 |year=2015 |pages=1355–9}}</ref>
==References== {{commonscat|Piacenzian fossils}} ===Notes=== {{reflist}}
===Literature=== {{Wikisource portal|Cenozoic#Neogene}} * {{aut|Castradori, D.; Rio, D.; Hilgen, F.J. & Lourens, L.J.}}; (1998) [http://serviziogeologico.apat.it/geositi/gssp/GSSP/PUNTA%20PICCOLA/pdf/THEGLO~1.PF "The Global Standard Stratotype section and Point (GSSP) of the Piacenzian Stage (Middle Pliocene)"] ''Episodes'' '''21'''(2): pp 88–93. {{dead link|date=September 2016}} * {{aut|Gradstein, F.M.; Ogg, J.G. & Smith, A.G.}} (''eds.'') (2005) ''A Geologic Time Scale 2004'' Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, {{ISBN|0-521-78142-6}}. * {{Aut|Rio, D., R. Sprovieri, D. Castradori, and E. Di Stefano}} (1998) [http://serviziogeologico.apat.it/geositi/gssp/GSSP/BUTERA/pdf/The%20Gelasian%20Stage%20Upper%20Pliocene%20A%20new%20unit%20of%20the%20global%20standard%20chronostratigraphic%20scale%20-%20Rio%20et%20alii.pdf "The Gelasian Stage (Upper Pliocene): A new unit of the global standard chronostratigraphic scale"] ''Episodes'' 21(2): 82-87. {{dead link|date=September 2016}} * {{Aut|Thompson, R. S. and Fleming, R. F.}} (1996) "Middle Pliocene vegetation: reconstructions, paleoclimatic inferences, and boundary conditions for climate modeling" ''Marine Micropaleontology'' 27(1): pp. 27–49
==External links== * {{GeoWhen|Piacenzian}} * [http://stratigraphy.science.purdue.edu/charts/Timeslices/1_Neogene.pdf Neogene timescale], at the website of the subcommission for stratigraphic information of the ICS * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060518100615/http://norges.uio.no/timescale/F5a_Neo1.pdf Neogene timescale] at the website of the Norwegian network of offshore records of geology and stratigraphy * [http://www.foraminifera.eu/querydb.php?stage=Piacenzian&aktion=suche Piacenzian Microfossils: images of Piacenzian Foraminifera]
